image.altText: The back of a police officer looking towards damaged and overturned carriages

props.synopsis: Rail authorities were alerted to the fatal consequences of a train and truck crash in SA's north when a member of the public answered one of the dead drivers' phones, a preliminary report by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau finds.

title.children: Member of the public picked up dead train driver's phone after horrific truck crash, ATSB reveals

image.altText: A SA Police officer's shoulder badge.

props.synopsis: The retired South Australian police officer is sentenced to up to two decades in prison for offending against the two girls throughout their primary school years.

title.children: Retired police officer jailed for 20 years for sexually abusing young stepdaughters

image.altText: A jogger runs past a mural with orange, red and purple colours and a wattle flower on a seawall

props.synopsis: The public response to a piece of street art in beachside Adelaide is under fire from the local mayor, who says both the artist and a resident opposed to the mural have been subjected to "online vitriol".Â

title.children: 'Nasty' and 'disturbing' response to mural along Adelaide beach condemned by mayor

image.altText: A close-up of a young person's face.

props.synopsis: Alana Tiller has around 3 per cent vision "on a good day" and wouldn't change it. She's among young advocates hoping for change in the way people talk about vision impairments.

title.children: 'It's something you can love about yourself': Why vision-impaired Australians want you to think twice about your assumptions

image.altText: A tight head and shoulders shot of WA Police Commissioner Col Blanch speaking while wearing his police uniform.

props.synopsis: Authorities in WA have leapt to defend the way police responded to concerns raised by the wife and daughter of Floreat double murderer Mark Bombara prior to the shootings.

title.children: WA police commissioner says it's 'wrong' to say nothing was done prior to Floreat murders

image.altText: A close-up shot of a shopping trolley full of groceries in a supermarket with a woman behind bagging apples.

props.synopsis: The annual rate of inflation has ticked up slightly in April to 3.6 per cent, from 3.5 per cent in March, but economists say it's enough to put even more pressure on the Reserve Bank.

title.children: Inflation rises slightly in April to 3.6pc but economists say that should ring 'alarm bells' for RBA

image.altText: Eight items of clothing are hung on black clothes hangers, including three singlets, three pairs of pants, and a white shirt.

props.synopsis: Whether you shop in-store or online, retailers are ramping up sales to entice us to part with our cash. But, as spending flatlines, discounting doesn't appear to have the same effect it used to, sparking warnings of looming retail collapses.

title.children: If you've noticed almost every retail store is having a sale right now, it's because they are. Here's why

image.altText: Two police officers standing by an item taking photos with an evidence marker next to it.

props.synopsis: Victoria Police have recovered what appears to be a phone as they search a dam south of Ballarat as part of their investigation into the alleged murder of mother-of-three Samantha Murphy.

title.children: Police appear to find phone as Samantha Murphy search centres on dam south of Ballarat

image.altText: A child rests in her mother's arms while surrounded by debris and garbage.

props.synopsis: Palestinian civilians in Gaza hoped that last week's ruling from the International Court of Justice might represent a turning point, but it has quickly turned into an argument about legal interpretation and world order.

title.children: A court ruling on Israel's invasion of Rafah has turned into a complicated legal argument. Here's why

image.altText: A woman in hijab covers her face as she walks through a crowd and smoke

props.synopsis: As an investigation into the air strike on civilians in Rafah begins, here's a timeline of some of the key events from the conflict leading up to the latest developments.Â

title.children: As the world reacts to Israel's deadly air strike on Rafah, here are the key events leading up to the attack

image.altText: Donald Trump has a tired-looking facial expression as he walks through a doorway.

props.synopsis: The first criminal trial of a former president in American history inches toward the end, as the prosecution and defence deliver closing arguments in a marathon session that stretches into the night.

title.children: A bored defendant, a surprise celebrity and the 'GLOAT': Key takeaways from the Trump trial's marathon closing

image.altText: Clare O'Neil stands alongside Andrew Giles at a press conference at parliament house

props.synopsis: The revelation comes as Immigration Minister Andrew Giles faces criticism for issuing a directive the AAT has used to overturn visa cancellations and keep convicted criminals in the country. Follow live.Â

title.children: Charges against released immigration detainees include kidnapping, assault, threats to kill and weapon possession

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Speaker details DPS secretary's conflict declaration
At least two former detainees convicted of murder or attempted murder were not wearing ankle bracelets
Breaking: Giles to issue new ministerial directive amid visa saga

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks at Andrew Giles

props.synopsis: Immigration Minister Andrew Giles will try again to deport almost 30 people deemed to be of poor character, after an appeals tribunal allowed them to stay on the basis of a directive Mr Giles himself had given.

title.children: Immigration minister tries again to deport offenders with Australian ties, as pressure mounts on his job

image.altText: An older man with grey hair poses in front of a black, yellow and white backdrop

props.synopsis: A Massachusetts theatre has issued an apology after Jaws actor Richard Dreyfuss used the event to air demeaning remarks about women and the LGBTQIA+ community.

title.children: US theatre apologises for Jaws actor Richard Dreyfussâs 'offensive remarks' during event

image.altText: Three sails of the Sydney Opera House jut out above Sydney Harbour. Red letters spelling 'NO WAR' are painted on the main sail.

props.synopsis: Twenty-one years since the historic Opera House "NO WAR" protest, the men behind the handiwork have revealed how they pulled it off â and how they view it now a new war is waged in the Middle East.

title.children: The faces and fallout of Australia's 'NO WAR' Opera House protest

image.altText: ASX in Sydney

props.synopsis: The Australian share market falls further as monthly inflation figures show price rises re-accelerating away from the Reserve Bank's 2-3 per cent target. Follow the latest news and analysis from specialist business reporters in our live blog.

title.children: ASX falls as inflation comes in higher than expected, pushing back rate cut bets

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Economist says interest rates need to hit 5 per cent to tame inflation
Construction falls as non-residential work flips
ASX extends losses after surprise inflation rise

image.altText: rows of solar panels on a block of land in an aerial view, green land surrounds them

props.synopsis: With upheavals in the agriculture industry making some farms unviable, a landowner in South Australia is encouraging others to consider repurposing their properties for renewable energy projects.

title.children: Regional property owners turning unusable land into money through solar energy leases

image.altText: A uniformed officer and a man appear to be having a physical altercation in a backyard

props.synopsis: Convicted drug dealer Rhys Aaron Johns is suing SA Police for half a million dollars, claiming his arrest significantly damaged his left retina and left him with other permanent injuries requiring "facial reconstructive surgery".

title.children: Drug dealer claims police 'assaults' caught on camera left him with permanent injuries

image.altText: a man in a business suit walks outside a court building

props.synopsis: Italian tourist Gabriele Cairo pleads guilty to causing the deaths of South Australian coupleÂ Cynthia and John Clark, and their daughter Jacquie,Â in a crash at a regional intersection in October.

title.children: Tourist pleads guilty over SA intersection crash that killed three members from same family

image.altText: Looking down from the top of Gunlom Falls in the Northern Territory.

props.synopsis: Parks Australia says it will plead guilty to allegations it damaged a sacred site in Kakadu during construction work in 2019 â an incident that set off long-running court action and a bitter dispute between traditional owners and the Commonwealth body.

title.children: Parks Australia to plead guilty over alleged sacred site damage at Kakadu's Gunlom Falls

image.altText: A close-up of a sea turtle's face on a pink towel.

props.synopsis: After spotting a request for help on social media, Emily and Callum helped Squirt the turtle make the 600-kilometre journey from Port Hedland to Broome.

title.children: Good Samaritans joined by green sea turtle for unexpected outback road trip

image.altText: A police officer walks beside a taller individual in a grey tracksuit along a street next to a police van.

props.synopsis: It is alleged the 18-year-old was one of a group of men who was involved in a violent home invasion at a Conder home earlier this month.

title.children: Teenager faces court, manhunt underway over alleged stabbing of two people who were left with serious injuries

image.altText: Leanne Benjamin wears black and leans against a ballet bar.

props.synopsis: As a dancer, Leanne Benjamin's body often ached at night. Three months into her role as Queensland Ballet's artistic director, she admits her brain often "thumps" after navigating the business side of the gig.

title.children: First woman to lead Queensland Ballet searches for what audiences want

image.altText: A young blonde woman named Ariel Bombara sitting while being interviewed.

props.synopsis: Nobody would have blamed Ariel Bombara for staying silent after her father's murderous actions took two innocent lives. Instead, she wants to see women protected and is holding authorities to account.

title.children: Nobody would have blamed Ariel Bombara for keeping silent about her father. But she wants women protected

image.altText: A side profile close up of Peter Dutton.

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton's political survival as an opposition leader thus far is an impressive feat, but the issue of nuclear power could be one that damages his popularity with women, a new piece of research shows.

title.children: Peter Dutton's a political freak of nature, but is he about to nuke himself with women voters?

image.altText: Brown-haired woman with Down syndrome dances in afternoon light on the back lawn of her home, wearing a sky blue and red dress

props.synopsis: For 17 years Jianna Georgiou has been a professional dancer with leading Australian company Restless Dance Theatre, comprised of dancers with and without disabilities.Â

title.children: Jianna feels powerful when she dances â whether at home, a festival or on the international stage

image.altText: a man wearing a blue polo and a balck jacket stands next to a woman wear a grey jacket and red scarf

props.synopsis: A Papuan who fled his home country because of tribal fighting says he is desperate to hear from family members whose village was in the path of a deadly landslide.Â

title.children: Papuan community awaits news of loved ones after landslide buries region

image.altText: Kerry Reece and her husband Brendan sit at the kitchen table looking at insurance bills

props.synopsis: Kerry Reece has been loyal to her insurer for decades, but a new class action claims her loyalty might not have been rewarded â rather it has seen the bills of customers like her inflated, lawyers are alleging.Â Â

title.children: Insurance giant accused of using computer program to inflate premiums of loyal customers

image.altText: Woman holding calculator surrounded by documents and keyboard on desk.

props.synopsis: While the cost of living crisis continues in Australia, there is some relief on its way from July.Â

title.children: If you're feeling too scared to spend money right now, some relief is on the way

image.altText: Torres Strait cuisine graphic

props.synopsis: At her local supermarket, Evelyn Billy looked around and saw food from all culturesÂ â except hers.Â

title.children: 'One deadly menu': The food mission to bring First Nations cuisine to all of Australia

image.altText: A photo of people digging at the site of a landslide.

props.synopsis: The landslide that struck Papua New Guinea's Enga province came without apparent warning and while people slept. But can landslides be predicted?Â The answer could help prevent future deaths.

title.children: Why it's a massive task to rescue those buried in the PNG landslide

image.altText: A young boy smiles broadly at the camera, while siting outside on elevated wooden decking. Grass and sunshine are in the backg

props.synopsis: Early education can have a huge impact on a child's path in life, but some kids are missing out. These experts say that needs to change, and they know how to do it.

title.children: Vulnerable families want to access more child care but can't. Experts say there's a simple solution

image.altText: A bird eye view of a pier connected to a beach.

props.synopsis: A US built pier off the Gaza coast has broken apart during rough weather, less than two weeks after it was installed.

title.children: Gaza pier built to supply aid breaks apart two weeks after completion

image.altText: A white androgynous woman with bright blue hair stands in a carpark holding a colourful portrait of Virginia Gay.

props.synopsis: Before this year's Archibald finalists are announced, we speak to a former finalist about all things portraiture â from choosing a sitter to adding the final touches.

title.children: We asked a seven-time Archibald finalist how to paint a portrait

image.altText: Woman in white shirt and blue jeans hugs a white labradoodle in a grassy field. They are both smiling.

props.synopsis: Elise Smith loves the great outdoors, but in recent years she's needed the help of an assistance dog. Here's how she has prepared her one-year-old Labradoodle for his biggest walk yet.

title.children: 'He's ready and so am I': Elise is about to walk the Overland Track with her assistance dog Lenny
